title: Optional.orElseThrow() without supplier
modernCode:
// Clear intent: throws NoSuchElementException if empty
String value = optional.orElseThrow();
summary: Use Optional.orElseThrow() as a clearer, intent-revealing alternative to get().
explanation: Optional.get() is widely considered a code smell because it hides the possibility of failure. The no-arg orElseThrow(), added in Java 10, does exactly the same thing but makes the intent explicit: the developer expects a value and wants an exception if absent.

whyModernWins.title: Self-documenting
whyModernWins.desc: orElseThrow() clearly signals that absence is unexpected.

whyModernWins.title: Avoids get()
whyModernWins.desc: Static analysis tools flag get() as risky; orElseThrow() is idiomatic.

whyModernWins.title: Less boilerplate
whyModernWins.desc: No need to pass a supplier for the default NoSuchElementException.
